title: World's worst team a concern for Steve Clarke as Scotland prepare to play San Marino
text:
The world is ill-divided, as the song says. Scottish Rugby hope that, if necessary, Scotland’s Pool A meeting with Japan in Yokohama – threatened by Typhoon Hagibis – can be played behind closed doors.

The nation’s footballers, meanwhile, have already been blown irretrievably off course for Euro 2020 qualification from Group I by Belgium and Russia and will face the world’s worst team before a vestigial assembly at Hampden Park on Sunday evening.

When the visit of San Marino was marked down for a 5pm kick-off, the Scottish Football Association’s hope was that, if the Scots were still realistic contenders, Tartan Army detachments from the Highlands and Borders would get home at a respectable hour before another working day.

Scotland’s smallest home crowd for a qualifier is 11,375, at a 1976 European Championships qualifying match against Romania on December 17, 1975, when Christmas shopping and expenditure took its toll of the attendance. No such mitigation will be offered on this occasion. Seven games into a 10-match schedule, Scotland’s ambition in the group has been snuffed out.

The SFA board members must be profoundly grateful for the possibility that they can yet attend the Euro 2020 finals – three games of which will be hosted at Hampden – via the byzantine process of the Nations League playoffs, in which Steve Clarke’s players have a semi-final date in March against Norway or Serbia or one from the quartet of Bulgaria, Israel, Hungary or Romania.
